text: this in particular sounded cool: A rotating-wheel Braille display was developed in 2000 by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) and another at the Leuven University in Belgium.[1] Both wheels are still in the process of commercialization.[clarification needed] In these units, braille dots are put on the edge of a spinning wheel, which allows the user to read continuously with a stationary finger while the wheel spins at a selected speed. The braille dots are set in a simple scanning-style fashion as the dots on the wheel spin past a stationary actuator that sets the braille characters.
these would be better than headphones: <http://www.rezonate.com/sdsu/671/assignments/informal/hoovervisitors.jpg>
I put that in the Google doc too
Those sound domes are really cool

they're definitely the way to go.. you just hang them overhead and the sound is directed straight down. no headphones to mess with or get destroyed or stolen and still a way to present sound to a subset of people present

had another thought about the braille dots just now.. what if you were projecting them on a wall and each component of the braille letter (each dot out of the 2x5 dot letter grid) was an object with flocking characteristics. so it would be pushed from left to right and kind of organically stray and return to it's letter formation
the interactivity part could be watching what happens to the braille dots/letters/song lyrics as they flow around barriers and such
this is hard to explain, basically flocking
we could integrate people into the braille flow too.. 3d depth scan and insert their outline into the projected wall and watch the lyrics flow around them
